title: PI name enrichment strategy
description: 100% of grants have NULL pi_name — neither CORDIS bulk CSVs nor OpenAIRE bulk dump include PI names. This is the single biggest data gap for funding intelligence (can't do PI-level analysis, collaboration networks, or track record queries). Multiple enrichment paths: (1) CORDIS ERC PI file (cordis-h2020-erc-pi.xlsx) — gives PI names for all H2020 ERC grants [already issue datapipeline-bvx], (2) CORDIS SPARQL endpoint — can query PI names for all CORDIS projects, (3) OpenAIRE Graph API v1 — includes PI names in project metadata, (4) GEPRIS scraping — PI names for DFG grants, (5) OpenAlex — links grants to authors. This issue tracks the overall strategy; individual source issues exist separately.

title: Data completeness dashboard and monitoring
description: Need automated monitoring of data quality metrics so regressions are caught during ETL runs. Current state: pi_name 100% null, abstract 98.5% null, pi_institution 98.5% null, total_funding 45.3% null, acronym 95.4% null. These should be tracked over time as enrichment progresses. Need: (1) add data_quality table tracking completeness per source per field per ETL run, (2) add completeness summary to 'make report' output, (3) set quality thresholds that trigger warnings, (4) track improvement over time as new sources are integrated.

title: [feature] Integrate UKRI Gateway to Research API
Validate quantum keyword classification accuracy
description: The SPHINQS report uses LOWER(project_title) LIKE '%quantum%' OR LOWER(abstract) LIKE '%quantum%' to identify quantum grants. This has false positives (quantum chemistry, quantum dots in materials science, 'quantum leap' metaphors) and false negatives (cold atoms, BEC, ion traps, photonics that don't say 'quantum'). Need: (1) manually validate a sample of 100 'quantum' grants for relevance to QIS, (2) estimate false positive/negative rates, (3) build improved classifier using multi-keyword rules or ML, (4) add is_quantum_relevant boolean flag to grant_award table.

title: Orphaned foreign keys and referential integrity
description: The schema has foreign key columns (instrument_id, call_id, funder_id) but no FK constraints and most are NULL. instrument_id is NULL for all 3.7M grants. call_id is NULL for all grants. The funder table has 14 entries but nothing links to it. The funding_instrument table has 0 rows. Need: (1) audit all FK columns for orphan references, (2) populate funder links for CORDIS (EC, ERC) and OpenAIRE (extract from source_id), (3) decide whether to enforce FK constraints or keep soft references, (4) populate funding_instrument for known instruments (ERC StG/CoG/AdG/SyG, MSCA, etc.).

title: [feature] Integrate Simpler.Grants.gov API (replace manual DoD entries)
[feature] Integrate OpenAIRE API
close_reason: Integrated OpenAIRE API: 15,793 grants from 10 funders (DFG, UKRI, NSF, SNSF, ANR, FWF, NWO, ARC, FCT, SFI). DB now at 70,677 grants.

title: Temporal coverage gaps analysis
description: The temporal data has suspicious patterns: DE quantum grants jump from 0 in 2004 to 7 in 2005 (DFG appeared in OpenAIRE), drop from 120 in 2016 to 25 in 2021 (likely data lag not actual decline). OpenAIRE coverage varies dramatically by funder and time period — some funders only appear from certain years. Need: (1) document temporal coverage per funder per source, (2) flag time periods with incomplete data, (3) distinguish true funding trends from data collection artifacts, (4) add coverage_start_year and coverage_end_year to data_source table.

title: Institution name deduplication and canonical forms
description: Same institution appears under many name variants with no canonical ID. Examples from German quantum grants alone: 'GOTTFRIED WILHELM LEIBNIZ UNIVERSITAET HANNOVER' (only form for LUH), 'TECHNISCHE UNIVERSITAET MUENCHEN' vs hypothetical 'TUM', 'MAX-PLANCK-GESELLSCHAFT ZUR FORDERUNG DER WISSENSCHAFTEN EV' (72 grants, covers all MPG institutes — no institute-level resolution). CORDIS uses UPPERCASE with Germanic transliteration (ä→AE, ü→UE), OpenAIRE has no institution data at all. Need: (1) build institution alias table mapping variants to canonical name, (2) integrate ROR (Research Organization Registry) IDs [see also datapipeline-agx], (3) resolve MPG to institute level where possible, (4) handle cross-border institution names (ETH ZURICH vs EIDGENOSSISCHE TECHNISCHE HOCHSCHULE ZURICH).

title: [feature] Integrate Crossref Funder Registry + ROR for data normalization
Within-source deduplication: OpenAIRE duplicate project_ids
description: OpenAIRE bulk dump contains duplicate project_ids within the same source. Example: project_id=217223 appears 5 times. Many project_ids appear 2-5 times. Root cause likely: same project registered by multiple OpenAIRE funder records or multiple versions. Need: (1) count total duplicates, (2) understand why they exist (different funders? versions?), (3) deduplicate or flag, (4) decide if these represent co-funded projects vs true duplicates.
close_reason: Investigation found that 35,960 'duplicate project_ids' are actually distinct grants from different funders sharing the same internal number (project_id is funder-scoped, not globally unique). Only 8 true duplicates (same source_id) existed — these are now flagged by the new _flag_within_source_duplicates step.

title: source_id format standardization
description: source_id formats vary by source: CORDIS uses 'horizon_101230906' or 'h2020_12345', OpenAIRE uses 'oaire_NSF_12345' or 'oaire_EC_101225859'. These embed metadata (programme, funder) that should be in proper columns. The funder code in OpenAIRE source_ids is the only way to identify the funder. Need: (1) document all source_id formats, (2) extract embedded metadata into proper columns (funder, programme), (3) standardize to a canonical format, (4) add compound unique index on (source, source_id) if not already present.

title: Funding amount validation and classification
description: Multiple funding data quality issues: (1) 143 grants show > EUR 100M — these are likely programme-level totals or consortium budgets, not individual grants (largest is EUR 434M). Need to distinguish programme vs project vs grant levels. (2) DFG reports 0 funding for all 32,198 grants in OpenAIRE — this is a known DFG policy, not a data error, but it makes German funding appear far lower than reality. (3) Some CORDIS grants show 0 funding while eu_contribution has a value, or vice versa. (4) 45.3% of all grants have NULL total_funding. Need: (1) flag/separate programme-level records, (2) add funding_level enum (programme/project/grant), (3) document known gaps (DFG, SNSF), (4) validate total_funding vs eu_contribution consistency.

title: Funder ID linkage: OpenAIRE source_id → funder table
description: OpenAIRE grants have funder information embedded in source_id (e.g., 'oaire_NSF_12345', 'oaire_DFG_67890') but the funder_id column and instrument_id column are NULL for all 3.66M OpenAIRE records. The funder table has 14 seed entries but they're not linked. Need: (1) extract funder code from source_id for all OpenAIRE grants, (2) create funder table entries for all 25+ OpenAIRE funder codes (NSF, NIH, UKRI, SNSF, NWO, DFG, ARC, ANR, FWF, AKA, FCT, NHMRC, etc.), (3) populate instrument_id where possible, (4) link CORDIS grants to EC/ERC funders.

title: EPIC: Data Integrity & Normalization
description: Parent epic for all data quality, normalization, deduplication, and entity resolution issues. The SPHINQS report exposed critical data problems: 100% missing PI names, 98.5% missing abstracts/institutions, GB/UK country code splits, duplicate grants across sources, no currency conversion, date anomalies, and no entity IDs (ROR, Crossref Funder Registry). These must be fixed before the data can support reliable funding intelligence reports.

title: Partners JSON field parsing and normalization
description: The partners JSON column exists but is NULL for most CORDIS grants and all OpenAIRE grants. CORDIS bulk CSVs include partner/participant lists but they may not be parsed into the partners field. This data is critical for collaboration network analysis and consortium mapping. Need: (1) check if CORDIS partner data is being captured during ETL, (2) parse partner organizations from CORDIS CSVs into structured JSON, (3) link partner institutions to canonical names/ROR IDs, (4) enable co-participation queries for network analysis.

title: Status field normalization
description: The status field has three values: 'completed' (12,716), 'active' (3,449), 'terminated' (119) — but only for CORDIS grants. OpenAIRE bulk grants likely also have status but it may be encoded differently. Check if status values are consistent across sources and whether 'terminated' should be distinguished from 'completed'. Also: should grants past their end_date with status='active' be auto-corrected?

title: Cross-source deduplication: CORDIS ↔ OpenAIRE overlap
description: CORDIS bulk and OpenAIRE bulk contain overlapping grants. Audit found 15+ exact project_id matches (e.g. project_id=101225859 exists in both sources). The overlap is likely much larger — all EC-funded grants in OpenAIRE (115,447 with funder code 'EC') potentially duplicate CORDIS records (54,884 grants). Need: (1) identify all duplicates by matching project_id or source_id patterns, (2) merge records keeping best data from each source (CORDIS has abstracts/institutions, OpenAIRE has funder codes), (3) decide primary source hierarchy, (4) add dedup flag or merge into single canonical record.

title: Country code normalization: GB vs UK split
description: Country codes are inconsistent: GB has 175,092 grants and UK has 6,173 grants. These should be unified to ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 (GB). Similar issues may exist for other countries. Need: (1) audit all country codes against ISO 3166-1, (2) create mapping table for non-standard codes, (3) normalize in ETL pipeline, (4) add validation constraint.
close_reason: Added _normalize_country_codes to dedup pipeline: UK→GB (6,173 records), EL→GR (1,303 records). EU kept as-is (valid funder jurisdiction). 106 tests passing.

title: Programme vs grant level disambiguation
description: The grant_award table mixes different levels of funding hierarchy: individual PI grants, collaborative project awards, programme-level allocations, and framework programme totals. Example: Millenion-SGA1 appears as EUR 19.98M (consortium total) but individual partners get fractions. Some CORDIS records represent the coordinator's view of the whole project, while others are individual participations. This inflates funding totals and distorts per-institution analysis. Need: (1) add a 'funding_level' column (framework/programme/project/participation), (2) for CORDIS, distinguish coordinator records from participant records, (3) split eu_contribution (total) from per-partner contribution, (4) flag records where total_funding represents consortium not individual allocation.

title: Cross-source deduplication: CORDIS ↔ OpenAIRE
description: Add dedup_of column + deduped view to eliminate ~54K duplicate grants across CORDIS and OpenAIRE sources
close_reason: Implemented dedup_of column, grant_award_deduped view, dedup.py module, updated queries/report/update pipeline, 9 new tests all passing

title: Grant-to-publication linkage for impact analysis
description: No link between grants and publications exists in the current schema. This prevents research output analysis (publications per EUR, citation impact). OpenAIRE specifically links grants to publications in their Graph API. OpenAlex also provides grant-to-paper mappings. Need: (1) add publication_link table (grant_id, doi, publication_source), (2) integrate OpenAIRE Graph API publication links, (3) optionally integrate OpenAlex for broader coverage, (4) enable funding-to-output efficiency metrics for the economist's perspective.

title: [feature] Integrate Keep.eu for Interreg quantum projects
topic_keywords normalization and taxonomy
description: topic_keywords arrays are inconsistent across sources. CORDIS uses ERC panel codes (e.g., 'ERC-2025-COG', 'HORIZON-ERC'), subject terms, and free-text keywords mixed together. OpenAIRE uses funder codes (e.g., 'NSF', 'AKA') and broad subject categories ('Physical sciences'). No controlled vocabulary or hierarchy. Need: (1) separate ERC programme codes from subject keywords, (2) build controlled taxonomy for quantum subfields, (3) map free-text keywords to taxonomy nodes, (4) add source_type tag to distinguish programme codes from subject terms from free text.

title: Date anomaly detection and cleanup
description: Multiple date integrity issues found: (1) 547 grants where start_date > end_date, (2) 43 grants with start_date before 1950 (earliest is year 9 AD — clearly wrong), (3) 3,843 grants with end_date after 2050 (some show 9999-12-31 — sentinel values). Need: (1) identify and flag all anomalous dates, (2) fix obvious errors (swap start/end, remove sentinel values), (3) add CHECK constraints to prevent future bad data, (4) investigate whether date parsing errors originate in ETL code.
close_reason: Added _clean_date_anomalies to dedup pipeline: swaps inverted dates, NULLs sentinel values (1900-01-01, 9999-12-31), NULLs pre-1950 and post-2040 dates. Fixed 4,433 date anomalies total. 103 tests passing.

title: Abstract enrichment for OpenAIRE grants
description: 3,656,773 OpenAIRE grants (98.5% of database) have no abstract text. This makes keyword-based subfield classification rely on title alone, severely undercounting quantum grants and other topic categories. The SPHINQS report found only 13,691 quantum grants in OpenAIRE by title, but the true number is likely 2-3x higher. Enrichment options: (1) OpenAIRE Graph API v1 may include abstracts for some projects, (2) OpenAlex links grants to publications which have abstracts, (3) CrossRef/Semantic Scholar for publication-linked grants, (4) For CORDIS-OpenAIRE overlapping grants, copy abstract from CORDIS to OpenAIRE record during dedup merge.

title: [feature] CORDIS SPARQL integration for network mapping
Currency normalization and EUR conversion
description: Database contains 13 different currency codes: EUR (1.87M), USD (1.59M), GBP (190K), AUD (59K), dollar-sign (6.4K), HRK (2.4K), CHF, INR, ZAR, NOK, IDR, CAD, SGD. The dollar-sign is not a valid ISO 4217 code. Funding comparisons across sources are meaningless without conversion. Need: (1) normalize all currency codes to ISO 4217, (2) add exchange rate table (historical rates for grant start_date), (3) add total_funding_eur computed column, (4) fix the 6,367 records with dollar-sign as currency.
close_reason: Fixed '$'→'AUD' for 6,367 NHMRC records. HRK retained (historically correct for pre-2023 Croatian grants). EUR conversion column deferred — requires historical exchange rate table.
